perturbation.original_text: The Master Franchise Agreement provides for termination upon bankruptcy. This provision may not be enforceable under Federal Bankruptcy Law (11 U.S.C.A. Sec. 101 et seq. ).
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement provides for termination upon bankruptcy. This provision is fully enforceable under Federal Bankruptcy Law (11 U.S.C.A. Sec. 101 et seq. ).
perturbation.explanation: The original text acknowledges potential unenforceability under Federal Bankruptcy Law. The modified text directly contradicts this by stating it *is* fully enforceable, which is legally dubious given automatic stay provisions and potential for assumption/rejection of executory contracts in bankruptcy.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 11 U.S.C.A. Sec. 362 (Automatic Stay), 11 U.S.C.A. Sec. 365 (Executory Contracts)

perturbation.original_text: The Master Franchise Agreement contains covenants not to compete which extend beyond the termination of the agreement. These provisions may not be enforceable under California law.
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement contains covenants not to compete which extend beyond the termination of the agreement. These provisions are fully enforceable under California law.
perturbation.explanation: The original acknowledges that non-compete clauses might not be enforceable under California law. The modified version asserts the opposite, directly contradicting established California Business and Professions Code Section 16600 which generally prohibits non-compete agreements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600

perturbation.original_text: The Master Franchise Agreement requires application of the laws of New York. This provision may not be enforceable under California law.
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement requires application of the laws of New York. This provision is fully enforceable under California law.
perturbation.explanation: The original text recognizes that applying New York law might not be enforceable under California law, specifically concerning franchise agreements. The modification states it *is* fully enforceable, contradicting California's interest in protecting its franchisees and potentially invalidating choice-of-law provisions that undermine California law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Corporations Code Section 31512, California Business and Professions Code Section 20010
